title: Architecture of Commons: How to Live (Al)Together?
segmentation: I will try to kind of narrate you's story in 10 minutes, which is kind of a story of our office, but it's also a story of experience for everyone.
An I think it kind of reflects our common struggles and hopes and passions, etc.
So we are London civilization compositions.
We're based in Rotterdam.
We are two people, but we kind of extend to 10 people drop down to two people.
We have kind of a compulsory flexibel let's say time and.

Um, This Is Us.
Anne.

I'll just jump in right to the to the first project, actually, which kind of tells the story tells our officers story, but then, as I said, tells the narrative of maybe the last five six years of what architecture profession to me and design profession has been going through.
At this moment I want to show a little video.
You know, let it cool.
Audio clean shoes.

Is done.
Yolo.
This was our first project I research project that was done together with for the Netherlands Architecture Institute in 2011.
The research phase and in 2012 the documentary filmmaking face.
We were up.
You're basically looking into urban transformation in Turkey.
In Turkey cities and we were traveling from Ankara to Bursa to Istanbul.

Doing the research about transformation and what I showed you just now was basically a piece of film which was broadcasted in national TV in Tan channels at the same time at 8:00 o'clock in the evening.
Kind of celebrating urban transformation in Turkey.
Since then more than 500,000 dwellings are both pulled down and re erected and this was the way that Turkey was dealing with economical crisis.
By urban sprawl and reproducing several housing, and we were researching this an at that time.
The guest protests broke out in Istanbul.
An basically the yeah.

So what we I mean we were looking into issues of as I said the relationship between construction sector and economical growth as well as like public space and gated communities that are being created for middle class and even lower middle class in Turkey and issues of like social justice and equality.
And when the protests broke out while we were obviously part of it, we it was impossible to escape, let's say Even so.
In a way, the process kind of changed the direction of the film radically, and we kind of started to.

We finished the film that say with us, with the right to the city and the notion of Commons, which came up really as a as a, let's say third option versus the binary opposition of the public and private.
I can I can already tell you like the the word public in Turkish translates to state, not people.

I don't know if you recognize this from your own languages as well and the public space also translates to, of course the the space that belongs to the state, not to the people, and actually coming up with the notion of Commons kind of gave people a chance to, or a possibility to talk about public space with the notion of common.
So in that sense we were really, I mean, the park became a space of gathering of.
That's a multitude, and and also the notion of public space.
Kind of replaced itself with the notion of camels.
At this, the notion of Commons and the way people gathered and organized themselves in themselves in the park, but then also later on, I think is very significant.
And in that sense it's also continuing the attention of maybe, let's say, goes away from the moment of conflict, when when the conflict is, let's say, right result.

But then what happens afterwards is kind of more interesting to look, and the initiatives that started at the time in Istanbul are still continuing the initiatives that are that organize themselves around different notions of comments.
They're still continuing, and this is in terms of a way of working in terms of working collective and let's say sharing labor.
And is the and space in the sense it's really inspiring.
And it's also it has been inspiring for our office as a working methodology.
I'm going back to the Netherlands.
It was around 2013.
The economical crisis hit radically this time and in the Netherlands, and the budget cuts have were happening for cultural sector.
Then I close down who actually asked us to do the research at the very famous Barlog Institute had to merge with David.
Often our friends would like talented architects.

We're leaving the country basically because they didn't have a work permit and they didn't have residence permits and in a way in reaction to that, but also in the in a way like, because they maybe didn't exist, we had to.
Start organizing our own lectures.
Maybe some people spoke about this yesterday, so I'm going to go over this very briefly, but we organized our own lecture series in in a bar in Rotterdam and this was really when necessary.

We were kind of putting money together from our pocket to bring someone to talk about the topics that we were interested in, so it kind of started die that came back and, you know, as much as possible, as much as we were able to manage with different people from.
Bloggers, an architects, designers, artists, but also like skateboarders etc.
We were organizing these lecture series which was soup.
Interesting, actually.
The kind of again like the way of working came very much from the understanding of forum and Notion of Commons and the production of the city.
Later on this.
This project in Bulgaria came up.
But I must say like a mommy.
I'm working with projects.
It's not necessarily, let's say, project in a way that has to finish at a certain time and has to have some, let's say, performance criteria which you have to accomplish.
But it is rather an idea that is picked up by several people and kind of organized and realized in several ways.
So in that sense, we don't necessarily claim ownership of the things that we do.
So in this one, one architecture, week, last year employed if the theme was determined as the Maritza River Ann you are from, we are now in the Balkans.
I could say, and so many of you probably know, Maritza River.
It was a regional infrastructure.
But then basically, thanks to the establishment of nation states, it became a border between Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria, but it also became a border between European Union and non European Union.
So it is the story of the River is actually quite full of crisis.

In a way it because it's went through several periods of Bulgarian state and then the communist state, and it came back to the, let's say, the recent Republic an all these powers, let's say, had something to say about about how the River should run funny.
But basically, especially the two hydro terminals, hydro centrals that were built on the River caused massive floods in 60s in Plovdiv, which caused heavy trauma with with people like you.
You get online and applauding municipality website and for one of the first things you see is about how you should behave by the River and how you should actually not go to the Riverside.
So carrying on this this notion of Commons and public space an.
How the River actually in time was almost taken away from people we kind of asked the question is, is it possible to bring the River back to the people and the people back to the River so we.
Organized several debates on actually interventions by the River.
I'm trying to go fast and reuse off abandoned sites by the River, and many of these are still there, so I'm quite happy with that.
Uh.
So in a way, this is also a question like how, how much temporary can be temporary?
Or could it become permanent?
Which is not a very new question.
Another idea, or again something related to what we're doing is about radical participation, and this is something that we have been questioning for quite awhile.
Is it?
We talk about participation, but is it possible to actually change things?
We do say our opinion, but do they actually mean something so this?
Or is it?
Are they actually changing things when we talk about them?
Or do we have the power to change things I?
I don't have photos for this particular idea or what we are doing now.
It's about the refugee garden in the southeast of Turkey.
It again came up actually as an idea.
Not really.
Commission or a project.
As such we were doing research about migration in Turkey and let's say the recent refugee crisis as we see it, an.
People we have met on actually the the way that the notion guest is attributed to the refugees in Turkey.
Even officially legally.
We were kind of discussing.
Is it possible to is what is host and guests.
So what?
In that sense, what is the vocabulary of hospitality and that became an exhibition?
I mean that was the main research which was.
Communicated in several exhibitions, workshops, summer schools, etc.
But basically in the end with the people there with the refugees directly we met we.
We had to.
We had to initiate some something and this is also actually something that I would like to discuss for the future of architecture.
How much we are.
We can mobilize ourselves to start changing things.
So the idea of a garden and kitchen actually came up from the refugee women that we met in Gaziantep, an we in a way kind of empowering but empowering in in terms of radical participation.
So in a way that they they can organize themselves on how we can facilitate it.
So in that sounds like we could be questioned the position of architect and actually I mean it's rather a bigger question.
What is the position of the architect and designer today or the artists or creatives?
Uh, among us, all of us.
How do how can we facilitate radical participation in this case for refugees, but time for all of us actually to change things?
And how can we organize ourselves to change things?

One is.
Here, this project was in Rotterdam, but then again I'm not going to talk about the project, but I'll talk about the idea behind the the work, which could be a point of discussion.
It's it's.
It's about thinking beyond the object and thinking and the object representing ideas and ideologies.
Actually, instead of becoming a product to be to be presented or two to spectacle.
We had to.
Make an installation.

But we wanted to make an installation in an empty space next to the River Otter in Rotterdam, and we were kind of relating to the River, which is kind of lost in the city Rotter Rotter River in Rotterdam.
I don't know how many of you have been there, but it's kind of not there.
People don't know that the name of the city comes from the River.
And the River was actually filled in with the with the leftovers of ruins from the Second World War.
So it's really aiming at parts of the city.
You don't even see the River anymore.
So we kind of, let's say, with the installation itself with cloth, and will also relating to the singer manufacturing at earlier, which didn't exist anymore, we were.

We kind of tried to reincarnate the River in the building, but then we also invited Taylors and fashion designers from Rotterdam to to interact and to kind of do workshops and also actually to discuss.
The Craftsman who is the Taylor, let's say.
And the fashion designer who is the designer, what, what?
What is the difference an?
What changed that is that the Taylor became the fashion designer, so this was very interesting discussion to also engage.
I mean not only for ourselves as designers, but also for the people who basically came to the exhibition so.
We're producing things.
Altogether.
I'm not going to talk about this one because I have two minutes, but they form like Adam is kind of is kind of a combination of all.
All these ideas and working methodology so far, which is happening in Shenzhen at the moment, and it's a it's a, it's an education platform, it's a learning platform.
But basically we are questioning the assumptions about Chinese cities, but maybe the most important thing to say here and to maybe discuss, possibly for the future architecture.
I don't know if you are how much we are alluding to that.
But how?
The things that I've been talking about in terms of horizontal T quality, but also like collaboration and and doing together and learning from each other.
Is it possible to apply it also in the design learning an actually learning across disciplines?
Thank you.
